div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,463] ALEXANDRIA, THURSDAY, APRIL 13, 1905. [SIX PAGES P.T. 7.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Berths can be definitely engaged beforehand. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles, Gibraltar, Plymouth, and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Monday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamer leaves Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before.
The express steamer usually reaches Brindisi on Wednesday afternoon, the special train starting at 8 p.m and arriving in London at the very convenient hour of 4.56 p.m on Friday.
The combined Sea and special train fare is 22.9.11 Port Said to London via Brindisi or via Marseilles.
Passengers having paid full fare in one direction are allowed an abatement of 25 per cent on returning within 12 months.
In addition to the above regular weekly service there are sailings about twice a fortnight of 5,000 to 7,000 tons steamers to London, calling at Malta or Marseilles.
TO THE EAST:

The Mail Steamers leave Suez for Arden and Bombay every Wednesday, and for Australia and China every alternate Wednesday. A steamer leaves for Calcutta, fortnightly, and another for Japan. Passengers can embark at Port Said.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MERSINE, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez weekly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for Port Badam and SUAKIN direct returning from Suakin every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m. a steamer leaves Suez for Jeddah continuing every other week to SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODEIDAB, ADEN. Intermediate steamers do not proceed beyond Jeddah but call at Tor, (for Sinai) El Wedj and Yambo as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: Austrian Lloyd's Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Venice-Trieste.

Weekly Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m. arrive Brindisi, Tuesday a.m. in time for express to Milan, Loverne, Paris, Vienna, Berlin, and London, leaving Brindisi at 7 a.m. Arrival Venice every Wednesday about 8.30 a.m. in time fro Express to Switzerland, Paris, and London, leaving Venice 2 p.m. and 11.20 p.m. Arrival Trieste every Wednesday about 3 p.m. in connection with Train de Luxe Trieste-Vienna-Ostende. Passengers reach London every Friday 4.50 p.m. Passengers from Cairo will find special through carriages and luggage-van attached every Saturday to Express leaving Cairo 9.30 a.m. and are conveyed directly to Quay alongside steamer. (Trieste-Ostende through carriage) and expresses to Italy and Germany.
FAR EAST LINES
Fortnightly Service: Alexandria-Brindisi-Venice-Trieste Line

div.head: DAILY WEATHER REPORT
div.p: OBSERVATIONS BY THE SURVEY DEPARTMENT.
REMARKS.

Yesterday was a fine spring day and similar conditions previal this morning. The temperature is high and a very light breeze from the N.E. is blowing. The humidity of the air has increased by 21 degrees.

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.
div.p: SUBSCRIPTIONS.—Alexandria, Cairo, and the Interior of Egypt (including delivery in Alexandria or postage to subscriber's address) P.T. 231½ per annum, P.T. 116 for six months, P.T. 80 for three months. To other countries in the Postal Union P.T. 273 (£2.16s.) per annum. Six months P.T. 136½ (£1.8s.), three months P.T. 92 (£0.19s.) N.B.—Subscriptions commence from the 1st or 16th of any month.

ADVERTISEMENTS.—P.T. 4 per line. Minimum charge P.T. 20. Births, Marriages, or Deaths, not exceeding three lines, P.T. 20. Every additional line P.T. 10. Notices in news column P.T. 20 per line. Contracts entered into for standing advertisements.
SUBSCRIPTIONS and ADVERTISEMENTS are due in advance. P.O. Orders and Cheques to be made payable to the Editor and Manager, Rowland Snelling, Alexandria.
London Offices : 36, New Broad-street. B.C.
THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE can be obtained in London at our office, 36, New Broad Street, E.C., and also at Messrs. May & Williams 160, Piccadilly, W.
THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE" IS PRINTED ON PAPER MANUFACTURED AND SUPPLIED BY THE LONDON PAPER MILLS Co., LIMITED (SALES OFFICE: 27, CANNON STREET, E.C.)
The Egyptian Gazette
An English Daily Newspaper, Established in 1880.
Editor & Manager: R. Snelling.
Price: One Piastre Tariff.
THURSDAY, JULY 13, 1905.

div.head: Sphrigao
div.p: The ancient Greeks had in their language an admirable verb, originally applied to the young of animales and then 00, by an easy and obvious transition, to the human kind. The word signifies at once to be overfed, to take no exercise and to behave as might be expected from snob a manner of life; and it would have been employed, instinctively and appropriately, by an Athenian to describe the present condition of the Liberal Party. Swollen into rank luxury by the surfeit of majority, and blundering blindly along, hon- ouroed by the charioteer of reason or of decency, the Government and its adherents are endeavoring to overbeat wantonly anything and everything which is, in the least degree the handiwork of their predtoeskois, regardless even though it be to their own detriment.

An eminent public servant retired last year from the theatre of his toils and his triumphs, broken in health and worn by anxiety: he returned to his county ungreeted by ovation, and remained for nearly a twelve-month, without pension or gratuity, in an unhonour- ed obscurity. Not he it was, bat the Government, whose loyal servant he bad been, that introduced into South Aria that slavery (to accept a comic definition) which served an Opposition with the cheapest and most in- sincere election or ever yet howled from the hosting's; and it might have been a statesmanlike, as it certainly had been a chivalrous policy for the new Government to disarm and facilitate imperialism by honouring a neglected upholder of Empire. Or-well might have been left alone.

But an incorrigible optimism would be needed to cherish .any such hopes in a Hooligan" Ministry; and it should have surprised no one that the first Parliamentary notice taken of Lord Milner was notice of affront and of infamy. For one little trip, generously admitted though in reality unproven, a great man was held up to public censors and a vilification the enormity of which staggered even ite abettors and perpetrators. ' Let ns beware," cried Mr. Winston Churchill, rising with his theme, as he proved the politics! Nonentity of his victim, "Let ns beware lest by pursuing him* too far, we recreate h.m." "The Ministerial party is strong," be con- tinues in his unctuous peroration, "and can afford to be generous." And the lofty-soled statesman sinks back amid thunders of applause,_ and his cowardly hedging amendment is carried, and seared for ever across the annals of Westminster.

For what, in all truth, has it served the nation, or even the party) Om bono, murmur, the astounded onlooker. It is not easy to see. Yet we will make bold to say that this amended motion, misconceived and ill-begotten though it has bean, may yet prove the salvation of the Unionist party; ti natura ntgai, Jacit in dignatio wrtum is true of societal endeavors in politics no less then in the realm of satire, and the indignant digest of colonies and mother-country is already calling with no certain voice for justice and for appreciation of mispriced greatness. For a year Lord Milner has rested^ and when he takes the field—and that must be at no distant date — he will stand forth strong in the confidence that be is supported enthusiastically by all those whose enthusiasm and devotion a statesman Would desire to command.

div.head: ROSE'S LIME JUICE

div.head: Housing Government Officials.
div.p: It is reported th*t the Government has postponed the soheme of bnilding houses for its offi -ials at Ghezireh.

div.head: Coal Imports.
div.p: The imports of coal from January 1 to April 6 amounted to 822.845 tons, as oompred to 164,659 tons during the same period last year. New Greek Hospital,
This aftern on the foundation stone of the new Greek Hospital at Chatby is to be laid. The preheat hospital is to be converted into a Polytechnio Sohool.

div.head: Hedjaz Railway.
div.p: The Turkish p*pers annoonoe that the Commission for the Hedjaz Railway has j oat p'aced an order in Western Europe for 6 000 tons of rails and 10 000 tons of sleepers.
Hashish Seizure-
The Coast-Gaards seized 81 saoks of hashish in the eastern harbonr of Alexandria this morning. The hashish was oonoealed in the drain which empties ont into the sea.
Cigarette Industry Threatened.

A petition signed by the moat important manufacturing exporters of cigarettes has been presented to Sir Vincent Corbett regarding the situation in which their industry has been placed by the inoreaM in the import duties on oigarettes in Burope.
English v. American Work.

Two hundred bogie wagons are being deli vered at Alexandria by the Leeds Forge Company for the Egyptian State Railways, to replace bogies of American design and construction, whioh, alter having been working for some time, have been found unsuitable.
Tha Bedouin Bergese.

Not the least agreeab'e part r f the sr.ooess of this entertainment at the Khedivial Sporting Clob, in honour of the visit of the Prince and Piinoess of Wales, is the important fact that the gate-money amounted to about £1,100. We congratulate the olub on this handi-omr financial result
Greek Independence Gay.

To-d»y is the anniversary of the declaration of Greek independence. High masses were celebrated at the Greek Onhodox Cathedral at Alexandria and at the Greek Church in th Hamz*oui at Cairo. The Consular representatives ot Greeoe attended the services. Hi* Beatitude the Patriarch Photios I. presided at the servioe at Alexandria. A reoeption afterwards followed at the Consulate.
Hotel Beau-RIvage Sold.

Mrs. 8t insohueider ha' sold her hotel at Ramleh for the sum of £'2 600. The purchasers are Messrs, G. and M. Rungnvits, win daring tfie past season have managed the b( te' so ably. Their Savoy H"t*l at Luxor i' *■!' knowD, having had an excellent winter sea-on. We wish them every suooees and prosperity wth the Bean Rivage, which is one of the prettiest aDd moat fashionable hotels in Ramleh.
The Pllgrimege Tregedy.

"Al Moayad," referring to the tragedy of the pilgrimage recounted in our issue of yesterday, asks whether the prisoner is liable to punishment under Egyptian law for his crime. 8urely Artiole 8 of the Penal Code answers the question plainly enough. As oor readers are aware the Hagi shot his wife during the march from Mecoa to Medina and asserted that a Bedouin had murdered the woman. The seoority of tho Hedjiz daring this year's pilgrim'ge made the statement most improbable and the maD was tbareforc arrested.
Alexandria Maternity Home.

We are glad to be in a position to state that the appeal made fo.* the bnilding fund of the excellent institution, the Alexandria Maternity Home, has met wi'h a considerable amount of snooess. A generous Alexandrian, who wichee to preserve his or her anonymity, promised the promoters of the appeal for the fund that if they succeeded in obtaining £1,000 he would give an equal amount. The committee have now succeed'd in reBohiog this amount and the anonymous philanthropist has sent a oheque for £1 000. As the donors mentioned in the first list published in our oolumns have in many 04ses 'no'■eased their donations, we publish tb6 total list in another oolumn
8psnd your Holidays at Mena,
The management of Mena House Hotel haarranged special terms for, residents of Cairo. Alexandria, and oonntry from the 10th nt April to the 10th of May. [Advt.]

Ministerialists have organised a demonstra- on here. M. The>tokis, in addressing the leeting, said he would not aggravate, but oold demand resources to organi«e an effective rmy and navy without which no aspirations ere possible. (Reuter.)

div.head: CREDIT FRANCO EGYPTIEN.
div.p: We hear from Paris that the Crédit Franoo- gyptien has raised a loan of nearly one lillion pounds, on what we have reason to elieve are very good terms, whih will no oubt benefit the present holders of ordinary hares.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The 8. 8. Asiatic Prinoe, from Manchester with passengers and general cargo, left Malt yes'erday, and is due at Alexandria on Wed nettday morning. The Cnnard 8. S Cypria sailed yesterda; evening for Liverpool with a full cargo. The Papayanni liner City of Khios lef Liverpool on Thursday for Alexandria.

div.head: THE FRONTIER DISPUTE
div.p: NEGOTIATION 8TILL PROCEEDING
ENGLAND'S RESOLUTE ATTITUDE.
LONDON, Saturday.

The "Times" correspondent at Constantinople says that negotiations between the British Embassy and the Porte for the withdrawal ni the Turkish troops from TaVah are still in progress and there is every hope of a satisfactory oonolusion. The Bri'ish Government is fimlv resolved to maintain the rights of the Khedive bat wishes to give the Turks every opportunity to escape with as little loss of dig- ity as possible from the impasse which they have been led into by the aggressive aotlon of their local agents. In well-informed quarters it is not thooght that the Porte is in any danger of misunderstanding England's attitude or forgetting that there are limits to the patienoe of the Foreign Offioe.

Nothing is yet known in official oiroles in Cairo regarding the question of Akaba beyond the faots already reported by Renter's Agency from Constantinople. Negotiations are being panned at the Turkish Capital, and it is therefore from London or from S'amboul that the first news of a settlement or a further impaste will reach us.

Ghsci Mukhtar Paoha has interviewed the Khedive on the subject and has doubtless given his Hi?hne"S a f >ll explanation of the Turkish offi ial view of the situation. As far as we can understand it, the Porte's contention runs thns : "Akaba is oun, Tabsh is part of Akaba- therefore Tabah is onn." Tabsh lies from 8 to 10 miles S of th9 fort and village rf Akaba. As it oomprises only one hot, a well, and a palm it oan hardly be described as a suburb of Akaba,— but the possibilities of diplomatic language are inexhaustible and we daresay 'hat, SUPZ will some day beolaimed as a part of Tabah.

In the House of Commons last week, Mr. Ruro:m n (Parii - mentary Secretary to the Lroal Government Board), on behalf of the Porfign Secretary, informed Mr. Ashley (U, Blackpool) that Turkish troops were still in ooonpation of Tabah. Negotiations on the subject are still proceeding with the 8nblme Porte, but the Foreign Secretary was at present unable to give any farther information.
BELGIUM AND ABYSSINIA,
A Be'gian Commission will shortly pass thmnph Cairo on its wey to Adis *bebs, in order to negotiate a commercial agreement between Belgium and Abyssinia.
PAY OF GOVERNMENT SERVANTS.

Lord E * ward Ceoil Pacha, Under-8ecrataty of State for Finanoe. and President of the Commission appointed for the betterment of the oonditfon of Government emnlov4«, has handed the Commission's report to Sir Vinoent Oorbett, Financial Adviser. The Commission in their report propose to distribnte the L.B. 19^/ 00 allowed for in the Bndget for this yo»r fnr -ha hanafit- nf amnlnvA* ranaivino a salary of less than L.E. 10 a month,
It is probable that.a further sum as well as the b^lsncg of the actual snm. will be pnt on the 1?07 Budget, for the increase of tfie salaries of the higher employee,
CAIRO'S GARDEN CITY.

This afternoon the first adjudication will be held in connection wi'h the apportionment of the lands of the Cairo Elpotrio Railways end H"liopoli» Oa«es C mpanv, wh;oh will be the beginning f Cairo's new Garden City If the scheme mee's with the approbation of the public an entirely new quarter of Cairo xrill come into being, and the pressing problem engendered of lafo years by the continuous rise in house rents will, it is hoped, be thus in great measure alleviated.
ARCHEOLOGICAL EXCURSIONS.

Tha ruins of the anoient oity of Tapusir's Magna are amonr the irrst interesting relina of the past in the neighbourhood of Alexandria, and'ha site has heoome quire aooessihln since the construction of tbeKhedive'slineof railway through the Marion! district. The r ins are on 'a lofty ridge overlooking the sea and include a most carious subterranean ohnroh, the remains of a palace dating from the Roman Occupation, the Arab's Tower, etc , eta. and the ride from the railway to the at cient oity is very delight fnl as the oonntry traversed is diversified and by no means merely barren desert.

The Alexandria Archeological Society have done well to organise an exonrsion to this spot wh'ch is to take plaoe on Mouday next. The start is to be made Lorn Wardian station where a train will be placed at the dispasitfoi of the party by the D-vir Khsssa. Thenoe the] , i will proceed to Behig, where horses and don ■ i keys will be in waiting, j A second exonrsion is fixed for the 19 ) ' inst, when the Western Neorooolis at Me: will be visited. There will ba a third exoursioi i on the 20th inst. to the Eastern Necropolis » | Chatby.

div.head: RETURN OF MAHMAL
div.p: KHEDITD PRESENT AT CEREMONY.

H.H. the Khedive presided over the ceremony of the Holy Carpet at 9 a.m. to-day at the Mastabat el M .hmal, Mohsmed Ali-square. This is the first oocarion on which the Khedive has presided over the oeremony with which the Mihmal is greeted on its return to Cairo.
Yesterday sf'emoon the Mahnoal was oon- veyed from Abbtssieh to the M-jhatned Ali- sqnare, large crowds gathering at the last* named place.

To-day's function was very largely attended and followed the nsnal precedent; the Khedive figuratively receiving the Carpet three times from Miralai Mohamed Bey Husni, the Bmir el Hag. The Ministers, the ulema, Ghati Mukhtar Paoha, and a great numbsr ot officials and notables were present, and a fair number of tourists, despite the lateness of the date, were to be teen among the Europeans present.

div.head: BEYROUT LAZARETTO.
div.p: Bey rout, April 2.

Dr. Clemow, doctor of H.B.M.'s Embassy at C -nstantinople and British delegate on the Ottoman Board of Health, Ahmed lUghib Bey, member of the B >ard of Health, and Dr. Balili, d 'Otor of ihe Greek Legation at Constantinople and delegate for Greeoe on the above Board, have called at Beyrout en route to Constantinople after inspecting the Ottoman hzaretios in *he Red Sea.

I !e»rn that the main objeot of the delegate*' visit to Beyrout ia the reorganisation of oor lazaretto, or failing a radical ref irm, the improvement of f-x sting conditions. The plan of rsd'ca1 reform embodies the erection ot uprolate fir-t olass accommodation, on atriotly bygienio lines, and other constructions, the zbole cost being estimated at about £• 0 f 00. Dnng'dering the important revenue of 'he Saui Sary Administration suoh a sum shoo'd not teem large, especially as it is to be devoted to :he carrying out of urgent improvement t one f the most important l*z»rettosoftbe O n mm Empire.

Dr. Clemow remained seme days behind h:s lolleagues, and sailed from here only on Sator- lay last. Considering the prominence of Brit- sh interests in shipping it was natural tfot re should devote an extra amour t r-f time and mercy on a soheme of this kind. Dr. Clemow ypifies Eng ish steadfastness and thorough' lass of method, and it wpnld Rat be too san- [uine to hope that our lazaretto, which has so ar existed in a primitive condition and been •ondnoted on mnoh the same lines, would be mlsed to a higher standard worthy of its rank rod importance. The rare topography of out asaretto, perched as it is an a h:gh oliff jit- ing into the spa, lends itself with peculiar fit- ipsg to the acoompli'hmeot of the prejeot the le'eTates have in view.

Whether this dream be realiz'd or not, it ia io be hoped that at least better attention will le devoted to the restaurant department,Some rery ugly comments and bitter oomplaints have isen made by first-olas passengers who, befog ised to every k-nd of modem oomfott at d teneral well-being, could not but grudge the ather high fare wh-ch thjy had to pay but *h oh did not seem to prooure them the rqni- 'alpnt O' a first-ola-s servioe. more especially a regard to the quality of the food and the nanner of serving same.

div.head: THE ABOUKIR MURDER
div.p: The details of the crime perpetrated on Thnrs- lay night at Abnnkir are as follows. A fishing leet from Southern foa'y comes every ye»r to Alexandrian waters and makes its headquarters it Aboukir. Two boats of thi« fleet were off Abonkir on Thursday when Giovanni Belli- 'emmine asked his oomrade, Coni' Macro, for i drink of wine. The latter answered roughly ind refused to give him the liquor, A fierce parrel e sued and the man dixemha'kad and [ .ught with knives on the s°a*hore. Mauro luoceeded in plunging his knife into 'he heart sf Re lifemmine who died m the stmt. ^

The aged fa*h«r of the murdered man, on ioe\ng his son -tretched a corpse on the beaoh, made for the murderer, who plunged his knife into the old man but did not inflict a fatal wound. The murderer was secured by the polioe ind taken to the Dalian Consulate at A'ex- sndria, where a preliminary enquiry is bsing held this morning,

div.head: ANTI-TUBERCULOSIS LEAGUE.
div.p: The LigueEayp'ienne contre la Tnberoulose has issned its annual renort and balanoe-aheet, which testify to the increa-ing good wo'k do> e by the league. A perusal of the report is oonvinoing proof of the utility of 'he work of 'he league and of the aorvioes which it renders to the power olass of the population irrespective of nationality. The necessity of a seoond dispensary has been felt for a long time and it is the intention of the league to realise this project at an ear'y date. The leagne forms an auxiliary to all the benevolent societies of the oity. It places itself at the disposal of all to tend the tuberculous and combat the extension of the disease in places where patients live. The institution is deceiving of every support from *h° pnhlio.

div.head: EGYPTIAN COTTON CROP
div.p: IS IT DETERIORATING ?
MR. LUMBROSO'S VIEWS.
Mr. J. Lumbroso has favoured us with a :opy of the following letter, which he hss kddressed to the "Manchester Guardian" and the "Liverpool Daily Post": —

'The question of the defioienoy in the yield >f the Egyptian cotton orops, mentioned by ;he Financial Adviser, Sir Vincent Corbett, in iis annual report, has caused some sxoitement n all branohea of the trade ; the prosperity of he oonntry depending entirely on the ootton irop, and the prioes at which it is sold.

Several letters published by^ttembers of the snd-owners association, and Mr Poaden, sec reary of the Khedivial Agricultural Association, n a lengthy report, attribute the prinoipal noses of deterioration to the restriction of rrigation during the hot months, by severe otations, and to damages by worms and the mtomn'a fogs.

But the principal oause of the deterioration nsntioned by Sir Vinoent Corbett is that rhilst f irmerly only one-third of the land was ilanted with ootton every year, farmers have eeu gradually increasing it to half, and even'' sore.
If we exsm'ne oar orops in the last 20 years, re notice 'h*t until 1890 they varied from
I 800 (X 0 to 8 0 0 I'O'i kantarg.
In 18*45 a orop ot 8 629 0 0 kantars was onsidered so phenomenal that at the end of be season, to dear hs bala- oe,Fully Fair w a dd at the sams prioe as miHdliug American.
8inoe 1890 the crops have he«n rapidly iorea«ir>g to 4 159 000 in 1891; 4,780 000 in 892; 5 220 0'0 in 1S98; wiring 6 56 000 ) 1898, the record erop, which has never been XQeeded.
The following are oar crops in the last 20 ears :

The abovK figures show that our orops from to 189H. in eight years, have more than ouhled. The general opmion then was that II e near fntare a orop of 10,000 0 >0 kantar* oald be raised, apd each year a orop of ,000 000 was expected.

But notwithstanding the oonstant inorease i the land nutin o onltivation, more especia'ly I Upper Egyp% where the prodootion has saohed 1 0"0,' 00 ka> tars, and the bet'er rater supply since the lonstruotion of the issouan dam -still even with a favourable eason the rxpeoted orop of 7,00'000 kantars as never been realised, nor has the record rop of 1898 over been reached. It is evident bet the same land of Lower Egypt that pro. uoed in 1893 6.2f 0,000 kantars does not roduoe now more than 5 2"0 00 , or an verage reduction of abont one karitar a feddan.

In reference to the deterioration of q uality i staple, appearanoe, and waste, whue for- i«rly natives did not give particular attention 0 tbe selection of seed, and while latterly i«re has been a general improvement in this sspeotPfaoili'iss for obtaining seleoted seed aving been given to the native farmers by the thedivial Agricultural Society, still, in spite f all this, the quality of ths la'e orops has sen decidedly worse thin th it of the former ear.

Tha damage* nansed by worms and fog* ave existed more or less for many years ; it beref ire seems fairly certain that the gpneral efioienoy in the y>eld and the de'erioration f qnality is derived principally from the gstem of plantii g option on the same land, very two years instead of time. The plant e -oming impoverished ia unable to resist any atrariea vt oiimate. su- h as fogs, exoasaive eat. or sudden coolness.
Many Dative farmers onltivate a small iroportion of their land with' cereals for their >wn living, and bersim to feed the cattle and he rest is planted with cotton every year.
It is certain that a linri'ed quantity cf end with a certain unmber of nsDds and tattle, ia more properly cultivated, irrigate I .nd attended to. than a mnoh larger quantity.-

The increased value paid for land might be ostified by the very high prioes of ootton nd the low rate of the money market. But he situation seems more serious for the pinners of the finer counts. SpinDers of thread rod other similar fine prodnoe most absolu- ely require oor higher grades and staple, and Lmerioa, the great ootton oonntry of the ror'd, is obliged to import from Egypt about 1 ,000 B/s a year, for her own consumption.

Several trials were made to plant Mitsfifi eedin the United States and other countries >ut most'v proved a failure, and never gave t practical result. But even in Egvpt itself, teither the 8udan, nor Upp°r E -yet which iaa some very splendid land th-rogh irrigated >y the same witer of the Nile cannot give the >auue prodnoe to »ervn as snb-ti'ute to the i«e prodnoe of the Delta.

All the land of Lower Egypt contains a sertain quantity of salt, and if we oonsider that the finest ootton in the world is planted in Sea Island, we might infer that the superiority >f Delta oot'on as regard silkines»,strength,and ength of staple is due to the soil teing impregnated with salt. .
Oar orop this year, which promised to he a ' record one, wi'l not exceed abont 6 000 000 kantars, and the higher olasses will be hardly i-uffioient for the requirements of the trade.

For the next season It ia reported that planters, induced by the actual high prices, are increasing the ootton enl ivatinn. The Irrigation Department promised to do its beat to rednoe the rotations in the hot months, and supply the necessary water for irrigation, and the Government has decided to fight by all means any appearance cl worms. Wbat will he the fffi -ienoy of th°se measures, end the final result of toe next orop, is a question to HBB.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: H.H. Prinoe M hamed Aly left Cairo to-day od embarked at Alexandria on the Austrian loyd steamer for Europe.
Lady Wingate also leaves for Europe to J-y.
Sir Edward Clarke will not return home f-utn gypt until after Bister, when he hopes to isnme his Parliamentary duties.
The Right Hon. Sir Savile Crossley and Lady nssley have arrived in London from the idan.
The funeral of Sir Elwin Palmer, K.C.B., C.M.G., took plaoe at Freshwater, Isle of ight, on Saturday last
M. GenDadis, Hellenic Diplomatic Agent id Consul-General at Cairo, who is now at thens. had an houf^interview with the King the Hellenes last week.
M. Meyrier, ex-Freuoh Consul at Andrinoe, who has been appoint -d Consul at Port .id, has arrived there with Mme Meyrier.
Mr., Mrs. and Miss Beresford are leaving e Grand Continental H -tel,Cairo, on Monday xt for Port Said, e t route for home for the mmer, by the P. and 0 S 3. Persia.

Wn regret that the names of Judge, Mrs. d Miss Tuok were inadvertently omit'ed >m 'hi list of guests at the reception he'd at e American Agenoy, which was honoured by e presence of ths Prinoe and Prinosss of ales.
Major LF. Philips,King's R yal R fls Corps, s been appointed Assistant Military Seorery to General Lord Grenfell, Commanding e Forces in Ireland.

div.head:
SOUTH AFRICA.
THE NATIVE QUESTION.
GOVERNMENT AND BRITISH PREPONDERANCE.

div.p: Lord 8elbome has opened the new railwa] from Klenksdorp to Fonrtcen Streams. In hii speech he referred to Natal and emphasise! that the people of Britain had no intention o interfering in the domestic affairs of Soutl Africa, bat the native question was not i domestic one. Britain had a joint responsibility with the colonies therein. (Reuter

In the debate on the Sonth African question Mr. Church:ll, in a conciliatory speech, sai the Government wished to see a preponderant of the British in Sonth Afrioa, bat he thongh that British snpremaoy must depend npon th Dutch as well as the British. Reinforcements have reached Greytown. / column starts on Saturday, commanded by Colonel1'Leuohars. Infantry will be largely employed owing to the dense bash. (Reeder,
A field foroe has left Greytown for Bam baata's supposed hiding plaoe. (Renter,

div.head:
PRINCE VON BULOW S SPEECH.
DID NOT WISH FOR WAR.

div.p: Prince von Bnlow's speech in the Reiohstaj disclaimed any wish for war for the Bake oi Morooco. He justified the German polioy on the ground that he wished to show that Ger many oannot be treated as a negligible quantity. (Reuter)
Prince von Bulow is progressing favourably but likely to be inoapable of transacting business for several weeks. (Raster)
Prinoe von Bulow's condition is improving. (Hmeasi

div.head:
ENGLAND AND GERMANY.
BYMPATHY WITH PRINCE V. BULOW.

div.p: HOUSE OF LORDS.—Lord Fitzmanrioe, replying to a question with reference to the Alge- oiras Conferenoe, expressed the deep sympathy of the House with Prince von Bulow and the German nation.

He recalled Germany's profound sympathy with England on the strikingly similar oooasion of the seizure of the elder Pitt in 1778. He paid a tribute to the wise diplomacy of Sir A. Nioolson, and said the debt that Great Britain and Europe owed to our representative was great. (Reuter)
The Russian elections appear to be going distinctly in favour of the Liberal parties bat the results until now are indefinite. (Reuter>
The Crown, the Government, and the Opposition have oonolnded an agreement ending th* Hungarian political deadlock.
M. Wekerle is forming a new Cabinet. (R.)

div.head:
KING AND QUEEN AT MARSEILLES.
STILL DETAINED BY STORM.

div.p: The King and the Queen have given £200 to the fund for widows and orphans of the Conrrifires disaster. (Rente*)
Their Majesties the King and. Queen are ■till stormbound here. (Reuter)
A storm has delayed the departure of the King and Queen of England. (Hmae)
A new hotel in the Black Forest collapsed daring the housewarming; 42 dead have been removed and 71 injured. (Reuterj
A newly-built hotel oollapsed at Tagold. forty-two penon* were killed and 71 injured, . Haven
